channel.title: Nature Physics
channel.description: Nature Physics offers news and reviews alongside top-quality research papers in a monthly publication, covering the entire spectrum of physics. Physics addresses the properties and interactions of matter and energy, and plays a key role in the development of a broad range of technologies. To reflect this, Nature Physics covers all areas of pure and applied physics research. The journal focuses on core physics disciplines, but is also open to a broad range of topics whose central theme falls within the bounds of physics.

item.title: Cavity electrodynamics of van der Waals heterostructures
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 20 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03064-8

Integrating an electronic device with a cavity can cause the electrons to couple to photons strongly enough to form hybrid modes. Now, the cavity effects induced by intrinsic graphite gates are shown to modify the low-energy properties of graphene.
item.dc:title: Cavity electrodynamics of van der Waals heterostructures

item.title: Electrons herald non-classical light
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 16 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03033-1

When free electrons emit light, an entangled electron–photon state is created. Here measurements of the correlated multiparticle system have been used to produce non-classical photonic states.

item.title: Vibrational responses of polar skyrmions
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 15 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03068-4

Controlling polar skyrmions — topological textures of electric dipoles — is crucial for modern optoelectronic applications. Terahertz excitation is shown to govern ultrafast manipulation of polar skyrmions featuring signature vibrational modes.
item.dc:title: Vibrational responses of polar skyrmions
item.dc:creator: C. Paillard
B. Dkhil

item.title: Ultrafast topological control
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 14 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03045-x

Exciton–polariton superlattices allow sub-picosecond switching of topological phases, paving the way for ultrafast and reconfigurable topological photonic devices.
item.dc:title: Ultrafast topological control
item.dc:creator: Hyun Gyu Song
Su-Hyun Gong

item.title: Experimental observation of a time rondeau crystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 14 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03028-y

Previous work on periodically driven many-body systems has demonstrated the formation of time crystals that break time-translation symmetry. Now, more general phases with partial temporal ordering have been realized.
item.dc:title: Experimental observation of a time rondeau crystal

item.title: Nodal hybridization in a two-dimensional heavy-fermion material
item.content:encoded:
Nature Physics, Published online: 14 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03060-y

Anisotropic hybridization between conduction and unpaired f electrons is rarely observed. Now, a lanthanide-based two-dimensional compound exhibits nodal hybridization, giving rise to heavy-fermion behaviour.
item.dc:title: Nodal hybridization in a two-dimensional heavy-fermion material
